results.title: Leaving My Country
results.creator_credit: Grant Hood, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: An argument with his uncle one night would turn out to be a life-changing experience for Grant Hood, a proud Kurnai Gunai man. Grant mentions the importance of his meeting with Kutcha Edwards when he first arrives in Melbourne. A photo of a very young Kutcha is also shown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Grant Hood, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: I'm home
results.creator_credit: Ron Briggs, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Identity is the most important thing to Ron Briggs. He talks about his father, his family and the traumatic experiences of being part of the stolen generation which separated him not only from his parents but also from his siblings.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ron Briggs, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Identity is the most important thing to Ron Briggs. He talks about his father, his family and the traumatic experiences of being part of the stolen generation which separated him not only from his parents but also from his siblings.

results.title: From the beginning to the resistances
results.creator_credit: Mick Edwards, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: ‘Me, my family, my nan - my mob.’ This is Mick Edwards’ story of separation, of a stolen generation or in Edwards’ words, “the kidnapped generation” and of healing and family and reunion.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mick Edwards, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Contentment
results.creator_credit: Noel Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A shearer for thirty years, Noel Atkinson’s life was turned upside down when he discovered he had Parkinson’s Disease. His new found passion in art and woodwork however has enabled him to live with this debilitating disease and provide comfort and strength in his everyday life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Noel Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: A shearer for thirty years, Noel Atkinson’s life was turned upside down when he discovered he had Parkinson’s Disease. His new found passion in art and woodwork however has enabled him to live with this debilitating disease and provide comfort and strength in his everyday life.

His new found passion in art and woodwork however has enabled him to live with this debilitating disease and provide comfort and strength in his everyday life.

results.title: Memory Garden
results.brief_description:
Filming ourselves and sharing the footage isn’t a modern phenomenon inspired by smart phones. It goes back to the first film in 1888 with Louis Le Prince’s ‘Roundhay Garden Scene’, a silent short of his family at home that demonstrates how we’ve always seen ourselves, friends and family as interesting subjects.

As advancements in technology led to more portable and affordable cameras, amateur filmmakers continued documenting their lives; capturing the everyday and extraordinary moments that moved and made us long before we were sharing selfies. These recorded memories have become an archive of our private lives and public history that preserves forgotten times, places and experiences.

constellations_primary.name: Making home movies
constellations_primary.description: Home movies have inspired the form and plots of narrative cinema.

results.description:
Filming ourselves and sharing the footage isn’t a modern phenomenon inspired by smart phones. It goes back to the first film in 1888 with Louis Le Prince’s Roundhay Garden Scene, a silent short of his family at home that demonstrates how we’ve always seen ourselves, friends and family as interesting subjects.

As advancements in technology led to more portable and affordable cameras, amateur filmmakers continued documenting their lives; capturing the everyday and extraordinary moments that moved and made us long before we were sharing selfies. These recorded memories have become an archive of our private lives and public history that preserves forgotten times, places and experiences.

It goes back to the first film in 1888 with Louis Le Prince’s Roundhay Garden Scene, a silent short of his family at home that demonstrates how we’ve always seen ourselves, friends and family as interesting subjects.

As advancements in technology led to more portable and affordable cameras, amateur filmmakers continued documenting their lives; capturing the everyday and extraordinary moments that moved and made us long before we were sharing selfies. These recorded memories have become an archive of our private lives and public history that preserves forgotten times, places and experiences.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → 11. Monument Garden
